III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
Section qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Sometime between 02/24/2024 and 02/27/2025, A staff at
DeRoy Hall was observed under the influence of/and smelling
like marijuana; this may have been a frequent occurrence. Staff
1

was observed to have bloodshot eyes; she would fall asleep, she
appeared "out of it" and would eat a lot while working. On an
unknown occasion, the supervisor helped the staff to "mask" the
marijuana smell; unknown how he helped her do this.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 2/28/25 via
phone. Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/3/25.
Youth A reported that the staff were cool and she did not have
any issues with them. Youth A responded when asked directly
about concerns with substances that there is a staff who came
into work high and she knew the staff was high because she
could smell it on the staff and the staff’s eyes were red. Youth A
identified this staff as Staff 2. Youth A reported that she saw
Supervisor help Staff 2 cover the smell by having her go to his
office and using his cologne to mask the smell. Youth A reported
that she knew this because she came back and smelled like
cologne. Youth A named Youth B as another youth who
witnessed this.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/3/25.
Youth B reported she did not have any concerns with Staff 2.
Youth B reported she thought Staff 2 came to work high more
than once. Youth B reported she believed Staff 2 to be high due
to her smelling like weed. Youth B reported Staff 2 had used
other people’s perfumes to mask the smell. Youth B denied
witnessing a specific time in which Staff 2 had assistance from
anyone including Supervisor to cover the smell.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/3/25.
Staff 2 reported she had no awareness of any staff coming to
work under the influence of marijuana or any other substances
however reported that there may have been someone who no
longer works there that covered the smell with cologne. Staff 2
did not recall the staff’s name and stated it was only speculation.
Staff 2 denied ever coming into work under the influence. Staff 2
denied ever smelling like weed at work and denied attempting to
cover the smell with cologne or perfume with Supervisor’s
assistance or otherwise. Staff 2 denied any knowledge or
witnessing of Supervisor or any other staff assisting other Staff in
covering the smell of marijuana with cologne or perfume.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/3/25.
Supervisor denied any knowledge or witnessing any staff
including Staff 2, coming to work under the influence of
substances or smelling like marijuana. Supervisor denied
2

assisting Staff 2 or any other staff mask marijuana smell with
cologne or through any other means. Supervisor reported that if
he were to suspect a staff of being under the influence they
would have a conversation, he would notify management, and
the staff would be sent to Concentra for testing. Supervisor
denied awareness of where the allegation would come from.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/3/25.
Staff 3 denied any knowledge or witnessing any staff including
Staff 2 come to work under the influence, smelling of marijuana,
or attempting to mask marijuana smell with perfume or cologne.
Staff 3 denied any witnessing or knowledge of Supervisor or any
other staff, assisting staff in covering marijuana smell with
cologne or perfume.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 3/3/25.
Youth C reported she did not have any concerns with staff
including Supervisor and Staff 2. Youth C reported she did not
have any concerns with staff coming to work under the influence
or smelling like marijuana. Youth C denied ever hearing or
thinking that Staff 2 could be under the influence or observed her
to have red eyes at work. Youth C denied having concerns that
Supervisor assisted other staff, including Staff 2 with masking
marijuana smell with cologne or perfume. Youth C reported she
has heard some youth make up things about staff to try to get
them into trouble. Youth C named Youth B as a youth she
believed to make up things about staff to try to get them fired.
Documentation review:
• Human Resources file for Supervisor contains staff
memos received for failure to complete supervisory tasks,
being unreachable while on shift, failing to complete an
Incident Report, and received a written warning due to
medication error.
• Human Resources file for Staff 2 details a memo to file
regarding timeliness/attendance, and a verbal warning
regarding attendance.
Analysis No violation is established regarding the allegation. Although
Youth A and Youth B report consistent allegations of Staff 2 and
Supervisor; the allegations were denied by Supervisor and Staff
2 and supported by interviews with Youth C and Staff 3.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
3

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
